abstracts.cdata!:
Latvia is one of the transition
            economies that came in existence after the end of Soviet
            reign. During late 1990s, the corruption and the lack of
            efficiency and proper mechanisms in the government system
            were the biggest obstacles in transition process. There was
            a need to improve service delivery mechanisms. People
            suffered because of high levels of corruption in the system
            that primarily existed in the form of state-capture.
            Bringing transparency and improving the working of
            government at macro level was important to ensure improved
            service delivery to citizens, and public access to
            information was necessary in order to bring accountability
            to the system.The Programmatic Structural Adjustment Loan
            (PSAL) project was initiated in 2000 by the World Bank to
            address these issues and to strengthen the reform process in
            Latvia. The program focuses on public sector reform, the
            privatization process, and creating a legislative basis for
            other reforms. The PSAL project attempted to bring certain
            changes through necessary reforms to reduce corruption and
            bring accountability in the system. Simultaneously, new
            mechanisms were introduced for improved service delivery and
            information access to the citizens. The project outcome is
            satisfactory, its sustainability likely, and the
            institutional development impact (within the government) is
            considerable. Although the World Bank Research suggests
            substantial poverty reduction through PSAL, the public
            governance issues under PSAL operations seem difficult to
            assess at present, as the change process will require time.

repnme.cdata!:
Latvia - Programmatic Structural Adjustment
            Loan Project

abstracts.cdata!:
The project outcome is satisfactory,
            sustainability likely, and the institutional development
            impact substantial. It is important to note that, public
            governance issues under structural adjustment operations
            will be both, difficult to implement and to evaluate,
            because change is only expected to occur in small steps, and
            over a number of years; benefits are rarely noticeable in
            the short-run; and, formal achievement of benchmarks is
            meaningless, unless embodied in deep-rooted, and lasting
            institutional changes. However, some lessons learned seem
            reasonable: 1) the choice of a programmatic structural
            adjustment instrument proved beneficial, in that it allowed
            a medium-term framework to be developed, with several
            activity phases, programmed over a period of time. This
            presents the advantage that, given the Government's
            commitments, potential resentments over tranche release
            exchanges, are less likely to occur. Furthermore, the close
            collaboration between Latvia, and Bank officials immediately
            following the Russia crisis, contributed to the
            precipitated, and exceptional financial assistance.

5086497.trustfund: TF026117-PHRD-STRUCTURAL ADJUSTMENT LOAN II,TF039528-LATVIA - MARKET STRUCTURE AND REGULATION
5086497.majtheme: Public sector governance,Financial and private sector development,Economic management

repnme.cdata!:
Latvia - Programmatic Structural Adjustment
            Loan Project

abstracts.cdata!:
The Programmatic Structural Adjustment
            Loan Project (PSAL) supports Latvia's reform program.
            It is envisaged that over the three-year period of the
            reform program, there could be up to three single or two
            tranche PSALs to support its implementation. The reform
            program will help Latvia return to a macroeconomic framework
            conducive to growth and improve its public sector
            performance by 1) correcting macro-economic imbalances, 2)
            strengthening the credibility of the public sector, 3)
            improving institutional capacity to deliver public services,
            and 4) encouraging private sector development through
            finalizing the privatization process and defining a clear
            and transparent regulatory framework. Latvia expects to
            achieve these objectives by implementing specific reforms
            supported by the World Bank in the areas of pensions, public
            sector management, human resource management, public
            expenditure management, privatization and regulation of
            public utilities and private business. The PSAL will also
            put in place measures to assist the government's
            anti-corruption effort and to streamline business
            regulation. The reforms will enhance Latvia's prospects
            for timely European Union accession; and provide a positive
            signal to international institutions and investors regarding
            the government's commitment to reform and the
            transition to a full-fledged market economy.
